work.p: The phrase "content to the ground" appears in the poem "Bunch Poem," which first appeared in the 1856 edition of Leaves of Grass: "The dead leaf whirling its spiral whirl, and falling still and content to the ground" (1856, p. 310). The poem was eventually titled "Spontaneous Me."

notesStmt.note: The phrase "content to the ground," which is visually distinct from the other words on this leaf, appears in the poem eventually titled "Spontaneous Me." Some of the terms in the list at the bottom of the scrap were added to the poem eventually titled "A Song for Occupations" in 1856. In 1867, "blacksmithing" was also added, but two of the terms that are struck through on this manuscript ("saltmaking" and "arsenal") were dropped.
